awd_titl_txt: Developing Teacher Noticing in Engineering in an Online Professional Development Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). The project will research how elementary (K-5) teachers in the Teacher Engineering Education Program (TEEP) program progress in one particular aspect of responsive teaching, noticing student thinking. TEEP includes four graduate-level courses that help them learn engineering content and pedagogical approaches. There has been little investigation of teacher professional development in engineering design. The work that has been done focuses on increasing teachers' content knowledge and familiarity in engineering. Most teacher professional development and research focus on teachers learning engineering content and process, with less attention on helping teachers develop new instructional practices necessary to help students navigate the complex, ill-defined problems in engineering.  TEEP focuses on helping teachers develop practices of responsive teaching in engineering design, where teachers base their instructional moves on what they notice in their students are doing and saying. Project research will also contribute to literature on how to support responsive teaching in web-based environments, expanding understanding of how design principles and features developed in in-person professional development settings can be implemented online.  The project will refine a program for engineering teachers nationwide, identify key features that are effective in developing teachers' practice, and create video resources for other professional development programs to use. 

The project will address three research questions: (1) What do beginning engineering teachers notice in students' engineering design work? (2) What shifts occur in teachers' noticing over the course of a professional development program focused on responsive teaching and how do these shifts correlate with key features of the program? (3) What shifts occur in how teachers' talk about their goals for students' engineering and their instructional practice? The project will conduct independent analyses from two cohorts of teachers of three data streams: pre-post interviews about practice; teacher-captured classroom videos; video-stimulated interviews, and teachers' coursework. The analyses will then connect these analyses to address the research questions. Videocases of students' engineering will be disseminated for other teacher educators to use in supporting teacher noticing. The research outcomes of the research will not only advance our understandings of teacher learning, but will provide evidence that teachers can recognize, value, and leverage students' diverse resources for engineering. Research on the TEEP program will also provide much-needed empirical support on whether and how online programs can be effective for teachers' instructional practice.

por.por_cntn:
As more elementary schools incorporate engineering design into the curriculum, there is a need to support and study teachers’ learning to facilitate engineering tasks in their classrooms. In particular, it is crucial that teachers learn to be responsive to student thinking in engineering. Given that design problems do not have one right answer and require innovative ideas and approaches, teachers need to be prepared to listen, make sense of, and respond to their students’ reasoning. Becoming more responsive to student thinking can also help teachers acknowledge and value more of their students’ resources for learning, particularly those not typically recognized in K-12 schools. With these needs and opportunities in mind, the goals of this project were to (1) study how in-service teachers learn responsive pedagogies in engineering design and (2) examine features of an online teacher certificate program that supported their learning.

         We examined 25 elementary teachers’ learning in the Tufts Teacher Engineering Education Program (TEEP), an online, asynchronous 18-month graduate certificate program in engineering education. TEEP teachers take four 14-week courses—two on engineering content and two on engineering pedagogy. We interviewed teachers, collected their coursework, and obtained videos of students’ engineering activities in their classroom to understand whether and how TEEP impacted their learning to become responsive engineering educators.

Overall, we found TEEP teachers made significant progress in becoming more responsive to student thinking in engineering design over the course of the program. One important way that teachers became more responsive is by learning to listen and make sense of students’ reasoning rather than just evaluating student answers or focusing on teacher moves. Analyzing their asynchronous online discussions of classroom videos, we observed that teachers focused more on making sense of student thinking in engineering at the end of the program as compared to the start.

We also conducted in-depth analyses of two TEEP teachers’ learning, studying shifts in their pedagogical reasoning. These case studies highlighted the variable and contextual ways that teachers reasoned about teaching and learning engineering. One teacher shifted from teaching the engineering design process as a linear, step-by-step process to instead recognizing the dynamic, overlapping nature of design practices. At the start of the program, she responded to students’ engineering work by evaluating what step they were on in the design process, but by the end she noticed and valued the integrated way students drew on different design practices. Another teacher shifted in how she reasoned about failure and iteration, coming to recognize the need to help students analyze unexpected design performances to learn from and iterate on their designs. These cases highlight the need for teacher educators to provide more opportunities for teachers to reason about the specific pedagogical opportunities and dilemmas in engineering tasks.

Alongside these shifts toward being responsive to student thinking, we found that teachers’ reasoning could tap into dominant narratives about who is capable in engineering and who is responsible for educational problems when they arise. These findings highlight the ideological dimensions of teachers’ pedagogical reasoning about engineering. For instance, we observed that teachers could draw on conceptions of engineering as applications of mathematics and science to restrict opportunities to engage with complex design tasks to only those positioned as “top” students. These findings motivate continued research on the intersections of the integration of engineering into curriculum and efforts to address inequities in K-12 schooling.

Given the pivots to online platforms during the COVID-19 pandemic, our project provided needed research on the design of asynchronous online programs that foster teacher learning. We developed a model for facilitating online discussions of classroom video, highlighting the ways teacher educators can support teachers to frame these discussions as opportunities to make sense of student thinking. In addition, through an in-depth case study, we examined how teachers’ own engagement in engineering design can offer resources for challenging classed, gendered, and racialized narratives about who is seen as an engineer and what counts as engineering.

In sum, this project advanced understandings about teachers’ pedagogical reasoning and responsiveness in facilitating engineering activities, as well as how to design asynchronous, online learning opportunities for educators. These understandings then informed the design of TEEP, which has enrolled over 100 educators to facilitate engineering activities in their classroom and become more responsive to student thinking.
